channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: It’s happening: People are starting to talk like ChatGPT
item.description: It’s happening: People are starting to talk like ChatGPT

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Tell busybody sister about diagnosis that could affect her, too?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Tell busybody sister about diagnosis that could affect her, too?

item.title: Trump calls for resignation of Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook in his latest effort to bend the U.S. central bank to his will
item.description: President Donald Trump issued the call after Bill Pulte, director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, accused Cook of mortgage fraud and asked the Justice Department to investigate her. In targeting Cook, Trump appears to be looking to open up more vacancies on the Fed board, accelerating the point at which Trump-aligned governors could hold a majority.

item.title: These places will be hit by big waves and coastal flooding as Hurricane Erin passes
item.description: A dozen eastern states are under weather alerts as the storm makes its closest approach to the United States starting today. Erin’s massive wind field brings risks of dangerous surf and possible flooding to coastal communities, even as the storm passes hundreds of miles offshore. See whether your region might be impacted.

item.title: A new name in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Most D.C. residents strongly oppose Trump’s takeover of city police, Post-Schar School poll finds
item.description: Washington, D.C., residents overwhelmingly oppose President Donald Trump’s decision last week to take over the D.C. police and order federal law enforcement and the National Guard onto District streets, according to a Washington Post-Schar School poll. And 65 percent don’t think his actions will make the District safer from violent crime.

item.title: Hegseth’s unusually large personal security requirements are straining the Army agency charged with protecting him
item.description: The Army Criminal Investigation Division, which fields security for top Defense Department officials, has had to pull agents off criminal investigations to staff weeks-long assignments guarding family homes in Minnesota, Tennessee and D.C., according to numerous officials familiar with the operation. The assignments have at times extended to residences belonging to Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s former spouses, the officials said.

item.title: Ukraine talks. Pete Hegseth. Jeanine Pirro. Voting maps. English learners. Hurricane Erin. Good life. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: D.C’s top prosecutor says her office will no longer pursue gun charges for people carrying rifles, shotguns
item.description: U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro said the new policy was crafted by the Justice Department and its solicitor general. The shift comes as the Trump administration ramps up federal law enforcement to unprecedented levels in D.C. and complicates the White House’s boasts of seizing guns as part of the crackdown.

item.title: Jeanine Pirro boasted of working to help Trump and GOP while at Fox News, unredacted documents show
item.description: Court filings from voting technology company Smartmatic in its $2.7 billion defamation suit against Fox News include previously unreported text messages and emails between the network’s employees.

item.title: ‘The city is dead’: As Restaurant Week arrives in D.C., owners see a decline in reservations amid takeover of city’s police force
item.description: Business owners are concerned that the continued surge in law enforcement could affect their revenue during a vital period of the summer.

item.title: Justice Dept. probes whether D.C. police manipulated data to make crime rates appear lower, escalating tensions between Trump, city
item.description: President Donald Trump confirmed the investigation on social media, saying the city is “under serious investigation.” D.C. government officials have questioned the unprecedented federal takeover of local police, repeatedly citing department statistics showing violent crime down 27 percent from a year ago.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Moving nearby exposes mother-in-law as ‘closeted’ nightmare
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Moving nearby exposes mother-in-law as ‘closeted’ nightmare

item.title: A San Francisco musical in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Trump offers ‘assurance’ he won’t send ground troops to Ukraine but suggests U.S. will offer support to European nations
item.description: President Donald Trump’s comments during a television interview added some clarity to the role the United States is willing to play in providing security guarantees for Ukraine, a subject discussed at a White House summit Monday with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and other European leaders. Trump hinted the United States could be willing to provide air support.

item.title: Trump-Zelensky. Mail-in voting. Epstein files. Teacher test. Measles risk. Hurricane Erin. MSNBC rebrand. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Top Air Force general forced out in Hegseth’s latest shake-up of Pentagon
item.description: Gen. David Allvin will retire halfway through his four-year term, becoming the most recent senior military official to be pushed out by the Trump administration.

item.title: Justice Department will begin sharing Epstein files with Congress on Friday, Oversight Committee chairman says
item.description: House Oversight Committee chairman James Comer (R-Kentucky) said in a statement the Justice Department “will begin to provide Epstein-related records” on Friday in response to the panel’s subpoena. The department, which was facing a Tuesday deadline to comply with the subpoena, did not immediately comment.

item.title: Zelensky arrives at the White House for a high-stakes Ukraine meeting with Trump and European leaders. Follow our live coverage.
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky’s arrival marks the start of a meeting that could determine whether a peace deal can be worked out to end more than two years of war between Ukraine and Russia. A parade of Zelensky’s European allies arrived earlier in the afternoon.

item.title: Columnist Jules Witcover dies at 98. Over six decades, he covered presidents, assassinations, civil rights and the Cold War.
item.description: Witcover was known as one of the best-sourced political reporters of his generation and wrote a long-running syndicated column with his Baltimore Sun colleague Jack Germond.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: After wife’s hysterectomy, husband regrets not having kids
item.description: Carolyn Hax: After wife’s hysterectomy, husband regrets not having kids

item.title: The judge who refuses to bend to Trump’s will: ‘We’ll do what’s right’
item.description: In an interview with The Washington Post, Brazilian Federal Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes said he’s preserving democracy in his country. The Trump administration, backing former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro, says Moraes is destroying it.

item.title: A historic stadium show in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Ukraine talks. Violent arrest. Israel protests. Coronavirus wave. Nighttime humidity. ‘AI slop.’ Pearl Harbor find. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: We stayed out all night in D.C. this weekend after Trump’s National Guard deployment. Here’s what we saw.
item.description: The Washington Post spent 12 hours on U Street as federal police roamed, bartenders worried and clubgoers tried to enjoy themselves.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Top European and NATO leaders will join the Trump-Zelensky meeting Monday, presenting a united front
item.description: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, French President Emmanuel Macron, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and and Finnish President Alexander Stubb confirmed Sunday that they will join Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky when he meets with President Donald Trump in D.C. on Monday. Ukraine’s future amid Russia’s war could hinge on the high-stakes and potentially emotional meeting.

item.title: Republican-led states to send hundreds more National Guard troops to D.C.
item.description: Three Republican-led states, responding to a Trump administration request, said Saturday they would send up to 750 National Guard troops to join the 800 already deployed in the District of Columbia.

item.title: ICE documents reveal plan to double immigrant detention space this year
item.description: Billions will be spent to reach more than 107,000 beds, including in mega-facilities, tents and at least two new family detention centers, according to an internal agency roadmap.

item.title: Hurricane Erin rapidly intensifies into powerful Category 5 storm, a day after becoming year’s first Atlantic hurricane
item.description: By midday Saturday, the storm had exploded from a low-end Category 1 to a monster Category 5 storm, with maximum sustained winds of 160 mph. It is expected to pass north of the Caribbean islands but could bring heavy rain and blustery winds to Puerto Rico on Saturday afternoon and evening.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: Divorced desi woman worries about talking about her dating life
item.description: Ask Sahaj: Divorced desi woman worries about talking about her dating life

item.title: Plug-in solar promises an easy, cheap way to power your home. Our columnist tried it.
item.description: Millions of people in the United States can’t install rooftop solar, because they are renters or live in buildings with roof limitations. But for a few hundred dollars, portable panels that hang on any sunny surface can pump free solar electricity into your home via a wall socket.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Putin gets a small public-relations victory, the Editorial Board writes. What happens next will be more consequential.
item.description: Putin’s short-term, public-relations win is less important than the meetings that follow.

item.title: Trump drops Ukraine war ceasefire demand, in a reversal that aligns him with Russia’s Putin, splits with European allies
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, with the backing of European leaders, has previously insisted that a ceasefire must be in place before any negotiations to end the war. Russian President Vladimir Putin has long pushed for negotiations toward a final agreement that would allow fighting to continue in the meantime.

item.title: Zelensky says he will meet with Trump in Washington on Monday to discuss Alaska summit
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky made the announcement after a “long and substantive” telephone conversation with President Donald Trump. He said the meeting on Monday would be used to “discuss all of the details regarding ending the killing and the war.”

item.title: Air Canada cancels hundreds of flights as a strike involving some 10,000 flight attendants takes effect
item.description: The strike means most Air Canada flights will be grounded, including international flights, a union spokesperson said. More than 600 flights have been canceled, with more expected.

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom and other Democrats roll out a new map to counteract a GOP plan to redraw districts in Texas and other states
item.description: The new California map would add up to five more Democratic House seats, likely wiping out the gains Republicans hope to make in Texas and intensifying a brutal national redistricting fight.

item.title: Trump, Putin signal no concrete agreement on Ukraine, take no questions after breaking off summit early
item.description: President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin emerged sober-faced from their closed-door talks, exchanging niceties but acknowledging that no final deal had been reached to achieve peace in Ukraine. Trump said he would soon be speaking to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, along with European leaders, to continue the push for agreement.

item.title: After more than three hours of private talks in Alaska, Trump and Putin prepare to take reporters' questions. Follow our coverage.
item.description: President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin's high-stakes talks Friday held the potential to end the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine and shape the course of security in Europe for a generation. Trump said on his way to Anchorage that he is optimistic that "something’s going to come of it."

item.title: Judge: D.C. police chief remains in command, but Trump can demand help on immigration
item.description: U.S. District Judge Ana C. Reyes did not issue a ruling but got attorneys for D.C. and the Justice Department to hash out an agreement that preserves local control of the police department. The judge also said Friday that President Donald Trump likely had the legal authority to get help from local police on immigration enforcement.

item.title: Trump, Witkoff and Rubio land in Anchorage for talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, with Ukraine peace on the line
item.description: President Donald Trump, who is joined by special envoy Steve Witkoff and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, has said he will know quickly whether the meeting will be productive and will end it early if warranted.

item.title: Michigan football receives array of fines and suspensions for sign-stealing operation uncovered during national championship season
item.description: The NCAA’s announcement Friday marks the conclusion of a nearly two-year process that began when news broke early in the 2023 season that Connor Stalions, then a low-level member of then-coach Jim Harbaugh’s staff, allegedly coordinated an improper in-person scouting and sign-stealing operation against future Michigan opponents.

item.title: The first hurricane of the season has formed in the Atlantic. Erin could intensify into a major Category 4 storm by Monday.
item.description: Erin will track close enough to the Caribbean islands to bring heavy rain, possible flooding and dangerous waves this weekend, even as the storm is expected to avoid landfall. The East Coast isn’t out of the woods for next week, with rip currents and rough surf expected. Bermuda may also see bad weather next week.

item.title: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem is living for free in Coast Guard commandant's home in highly unusual arrangement
item.description: Noem recently moved into Quarters 1, a spacious waterfront residence on a military base where the Coast Guard commandant typically resides and is not paying rent. Her spokesperson says the arrangement is because of concerns over the secretary's safety.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: D.C. attorney general sues Trump administration as federal government seeks to exert more control over city's police department
item.description: The announcement came hours after U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi ordered sweeping changes to law enforcement policies in the city and said a Trump official should assume all duties and responsibilities of the police chief.

item.title: Trump and Putin. ICE expansion. D.C. police. Kids’ vaccines. Looming hurricane. Alcohol poll. Hairy toothpaste. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Bowser, D.C. attorney general reject Bondi move to name emergency police commissioner in first major pushback to federal takeover
item.description: Mayor Muriel E. Bowser and D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb said the order by Attorney General Pam Bondi — which also ordered sweeping changes to D.C. police polices — was unlawful and suggested they would not comply.
